title: Career Paths in Research - Structural Change

author: Karin Uphoff, uphoff pr & marketing GmbH

segmentation: Let me now invite Doctor Karen Uphoff.
She's a managing director and has her own company up of PR and marketing.
Here is that right.
Current CV is very impressive.

She developed strategic PR concepts for her clients, but her companies mainly known and famous for its innovative tools and has received several awards for innovation and the Preneurship and family friendly policies.
Karen is a successful and committed and the preneur.
As I heard and Wow mother of six.
So she is a role model for many many women in business.
She is a member of European Network of Female Intrapreneurship Ambassadors, director of the Organization of German Businesswomen and press coordinator of the Management Network E. WMD.
I don't know what's that, sorry.
And there she runs a special support service for women.
It's called the Ladies management consulting, so the floor is yours.
Yeah, ladies and gentlemen, when my husband and me decided to have babies.
He was writing and my husband was writing his doctoral thesis and I had just started my first job.
And when we decided to have a baby, people called me crazy.
You will end in poverty and never get an interesting job.
If you don't invest all your time in work, they said.
We didn't listen, bought a house.
I passed an additional examine PR and had my first child boy.
When we decided to have a second baby, people called me stupid.
You will never be able to write your doctoral thesis, they said.
That's what I wanted to do during that time I didn't listen, started my thesis, work part time, and had my second child about a girl.
When we decided to have a third baby.
People asked whether we were religious and felt oblique to have so many children.
I didn't listen finish my doctoral thesis.
Had my third child boy again and started a new job.
When we decided to have the 4th baby, people said our house would be too small.
This time they were right.
So we bought a larger house and a larger car.
I had my first force child, a girl.
And I said yes when I was asked to be head of project management.
And my husband started a new job where he could work part time.
When we decided to have our fifth baby over children was so happy that they told everyone about it.
And then someone sent us in anonymous letter and asked if we hadn't heard about worlds overpopulation.
We didn't care.
I had my fifth child, a girl, and started as a leader of a big business unit.
When we decided to have the sick child, my parents in law called us crazy.
And my boss told me not to talk to clients about children.
I listened but nevertheless loved it to have my six child, a boy.
So we have three girls, three boys, Boy girl boy, girl, Girl, boy, let's gender equality.
I became managing director.
Then I quit the job, founded my own company in 2003, a PR agency.
My God, some employees we grew.
I bought an office house and in the following years I received several awards among them awards for innovation, entrepreneurship and family friendly policies.
Besides that, I became an addition part time teacher at University.
I founded my second company, the Institute for Applied PR.
Where do workshops, especially for students or for for organizations?
My husband train drops again.
Ann Pasta special exam for Epidemiology.
And then again, someone sent us an anonymous letter and told me that women like me would ruin the children and that it was the fault of women like me that kids nowadays are not behaving well.
And that German is breaking down because of that.
I didn't enjoy reading that, but thought OK, this is Germany as well.
Today I have a third company you already heard about it.
The latest management consulting.
And I'm supporting women having children and a good job.
And to be happy with both.
And there my PR helps.
I help them being visible, for example with a special women PR and with special networking.

I'm a member of the European Network of Ambassadors for female Intrapreneurship and I like that very much because we meet a lot of interesting women and that's what we heard today and yesterday we need this networks and we have to give strength to each other.
And you heard I'm regional director of the organization of German Business women, an press coordinator of the European Women's Management Development International network Hardward.
My husband has trained drops again and is now one of the leading epidemiologists in Germany.
And our children.
Now they are not neglect neglected.
That's the question I'm often asked.
Do your children know you at all?
Yes, they know me.
And they had good times, and they had bad times like children have.
And they were sad.
And they were proud about me being a working mom and proud and said about her father being working father, our eldest son now is studying math medical science in Hungary.
Our number 2 and that's what we talked about this morning.
Got Corona, has 5 Four sisters and one brother and she said it's only number 123456 and it's the same in our family.
So our number one is medical science.
Our #2 is going to be teacher our #3 is studying economic engineering and our #4 is taking her exams right now and is going to study chemistry.
And #5 and six are still at home, Fortunately.
And I will have to say we have a very close relationship to the children and the children have that among themselves.
And if you ask them, they would say yes.
We want to have several children and we want to be working parents.
So why do I tell you these stories?
It's because I wanted to show you the ambivalence in Germany.
On one hand, a woman can do everything she wants to do.
She can be a manager and entrepreneur, a translor administer with seven child children.
She can have several children and have good career.
On the other hand, it is still not the usual way you saw the the charts for Germany.
There, horrible.
There's still lots of resentments about working women and especially working months.
And yesterday we heard about this hidden messages.
And yes, there are lot of hidden messages and you have to be strong in Germany not to listen to them and to say OK, I'll stay at home and we still have.
A lot of stereotypes, and that's what makes it so exhausting to be to have a career.
But let us see what the situation in Germany is like we.
Have about 82 million inhabitants, 51 of them women, 49 men.
Students 2.2 million students and in 1987 they were much more male students.
Nowadays, it's nearly equal.
We have 52% female students and 48 female.
But as we heard yesterday, it's the same in Germany.
The women concentrate on certain fields of study areas.
And if you look here, have a look into the enterprises and organizations.
We have about 41 million employed persons and we have about 4.9 million part-time workers and you can see that's a typical female thing.
87% of the part time workers are women and only 13 are men.
And let us look what's the way in enterprises.
We have 2.3 million entrepreneurs.
And again you have the same 70% Aman, only 30% of women.
And if you have a look.
A closer look you see in companies with big economic impact, you have 82%.
Men.
As entrepreneur and only 18% women, and it's a bit better in small companies and a bit better in for mailing in companies for incidental earnings.
It's a typical way that women have regular job and have a small enterprise besides it or they are at home and have a small enterprise besides it.
And it's getting even worse.
We only have less than 2% female CEOs.
We have less than 11% female board members.
And still in 30% of the top 200.
Organizations we have no female board member.
And that's Germany.
Lot of people who come to Germany can't believe it because we have a lot of programs and a lot of.
Discussions about gender.
Challenge, but we still have these bad.
Bad presentation of this under representation of women in this Cor.
Board member areas.
So when I say we have a lot of support for women.
We heard about it yesterday and today, so I only have a.
Only point out some of them we have.
Nationwide programs to support women in higher education and studies.
To promote equal, equal opportunities to promote women in science and research and to promote women in leadership positions.
In addition, we have special.
Supports in towns in areas, for example, in Berlin, the program to promote women in science teaching and research and so on.
So they're regional supports of women.
We have special thematic areas to support women, especially in science and research.
And we have a lot of.
Lot of programs and and initiatives to have more women in as a board member.
It's, for example feeder, an initiative for more women on the boards, or the same that nurnberger resolution.

And the last month alot of female journalists had the poor quarter for more women in editorial management and the organizations of business women and business women in management have special special programs and special support for women.
To have to be present in pot as a board member.
So.
More and more people, that's what I see.
Understand that having women in business is no question of emancipation, but is an economic necessity.
And we have a lot of supports and we have a lot of kindergarten and a lot of support for helping women and men or helping parents with their children.
But I think one of the most important points in Germany is that working culture, and that's what we heard before has to be changed.
Being in the being at office all day and dividing life into work and private time still is the usual way.
Alternative working models are not common yet.
And.
Yes it is.
We have this linear career wastes and there's no thinking about that.
It could work in a different way, but there was a study with young people and they were asked about their favorite way of living and working.
And there you can see that there's nearly no difference between men and women anymore.
Men and women are women and men say yes, we want to have a good job.
And yes, we want to have time for our children.
We want to have children, want to have time for them.
I'm very excited about how things will turn out in future and whether young people will achieve to change working culture and to share business and family work.
I myself would strongly support them.
Thank you.
